name: asherdan
text: A comment left by asherdan was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by straw, Thorfinn, NotGodot, Yossarian, DiamondMonster, tttt2, Moraiat, atticusonline, prowle4763, SenseiHollywood, SPECTRE)

name: atom
text: One thousand percent agreed.  I use it so often that even my non-Achewood-reading friends have started to say it as well.

name: sargasm
text: If I ever wear a tie, it will have a spork in it.

name: soticoto
text: A comment left by soticoto was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by lamboyster, zcross00, fosters, robbingdog, blueshoc12, RedGuy, aHatOfPig)

name: bjorntd
text: This is my tie. Why is it broken?

name: hikikomori
text: Because of a problem?

name: smoothjimmyapollo
text: I never realized Ray spilled his drink off the top of his computer monitor when I first read this.

name: ssddr
text: Yeah, i was never sure if it spilt or if he hit his monitor in a fit of rage and knocked it over.

name: jordstar
text: Regardless of how it happened, the spilled drink got a vicious thumbs-down.

name: thegrayhoodie
text: It almost looks like the word balloons knocked it over.

name: scorpio_nadir
text:
He bangs the desk with that full belly.
Gawd. Scrapes off the caviar! Bomp!

name: niggar
text: These are almost the exact same panels as the last time Ray was on the phone .

name: gormster
text: A comment left by gormster was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by fmercury, Crater12, AtlanticCity, stormagnet)

name: setzkin
text: You are mistaken, the eyebrows are completely different in the first three panels!

name: mockereo
text:
I have a feeling that spilling a martini off the top of a computer monitor is one of the most common things Ray does while using the phone.

Maybe even more common than talking on the phone.

name: numberkillinger
text: I think it is what would be described as a "joke"

name: snowman
text: Onstad will be telling a lot of them here tonight.

name: fuzzyshoo
text: it is not the first time.

name: rayonatoilet
text: Actually, this is the second time he's done this EXACT thing. And I don't exactly know why it has happened again.

name: jujubeesforjesus
text: Bensington Butters lacks so much class that Ray's vodkatini spontaneously suicides.

name: spinynorman
text:
Vodkatini has nothing on the gin martini for class.

Thanks, James Bond, for making people think a real martini is made with vodka.

name: terebikun
text:
Don't let the movies get you down. This is how James Bond actually orders martinis: Three measures of Gordon's, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it's ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon-peel. Got it?

I think he also has them dry and in a champagne goblet. Cause he's a classy fuck.

name: spinynorman
text: Lillet is actually a very good and often underused mixer.

name: terebikun
text: Probably because I don't think it's made anymore.  Bartenders I meet don't even know what it is.  Then again, these same bartenders don't even know how to make a sidecar, so take of that what you will.  I hate living in a college town.

name: mattfish
text:
oh, it's still made. It's not quite the same as the Vesper days, but it's out there. Check the fortified wine section.

The Vesper isn't a martini, though.

name: bjorntd
text: That's how he makes up a drink he eventually names a "Vesper" in Casino Royale. The literary Bond actually drinks hell of bourbon and water.

name: spinynorman
text: Wasn't the Vesper the original martini recipe from the novels, though?

name: xiaomimi
text: Nonsense!  Cocktails are too restricted in number of potential ingredients to allow for such fuzzy category placement, if you ask me.  To my mind, gin   dry vermouth   olive cannot comfortably morph into gin   vodka   Lillet   twist.  Perfect and dirty martinis I can accept, since they involve intensification/variation on the original ingredients, but not the more drastic substitution of Lillet for vermouth.  The substitution of vodka for gin is, of course, an ongoing matter of controversy, and I will leave that particular minefield to those more committed to the battle.

name: xiaomimi
text: Oh dear, those plus signs.

name: bjorntd
text: Well, I wouldn't call it a "martini" per se, but yeah, he orders that drink. Once. To show off. And then he orders another one later in that book. For the rest of the novels, he's basically on bourbon and water and gin-tonics and daiquiris. He's got quite a bit of alcoholic range. I rather like how he gets his gin-tonics. Double, with a whole lime that he cuts himself in half, squeezed slightly and  dropped in, with tonic poured in afterwards.

name: omegatron
text: James Bond cuts himself in half with a lime?

name: presterjohn
text: The Proper gin and tonic is equal parts gin (Plymouth Navy Strength preferred) and tonic water with a lemon and a dash of bitters. It is so good I am drinking one now .

name: terebikun
text: I don't think he ordered it more than the one time, but he did name it the Vesper Martini because he said it was all he wanted to drink, so he assumed he drank it again.

name: terebikun
text: Or *I assumed he drank it again.  Whatever.

name: mattfish
text: Then he never drank one again, because "the bitch is dead".

name: terebikun
text: Quantum of Solace'd

name: stormagnet
text: Shaken martinis are a fucking travesty.

name: spinynorman
text:
I believe the shaken martini is a French innovation, at least according to my grandpa, who always stirred his in an enormous glass pitcher.

I prefer either, really.

name: stormagnet
text: How do you keep them from getting all diluted? Or is that part of the preference? I'll admit, the finer points of these things can escape me. That whole adding water to scotch thing, for instance. I've heard that it's supposed to bring out the flavor or something, but it just seems wrong.

name: spinynorman
text:
I believe the water-into-scotch theorem is meant to lessen the alcoholic sting of the drink, thus making the more subtle fragrances of the malt more noticeable, as they were probably overridden by the whole "holy shit, this is booze" effect.

A martini is going to get diluted no matter what, I believe. Stirring seems like it's more likely to dilute it than shaking it, though shaking it is going to add chips of ice into the gin. There are different shakers that strain these out with a wire mesh, though.

name: sciencey
text:
I prefer to drink my scotch (or irish whiskey) with rocks, letting the melt just enough to cool it down and dilute it more subtly than I could possibly manage with a faucet or a pitcher. Reduces the "oh, booze!" effect and is tastier for me.

Also, shaking a martini "bruises" the alcohol by exposing it more thoroughly to air (specifically oxygen, a reactive species.) This makes it taste more strongly. Both stirring and shaking introduce water.

name: mattfish
text:
The more I drink whisk(e)ys on the rocks, the more I find the chill (not the dilution) kills the depth of the drink. I usually go scotch with a splash of soda and bourbon with a splash of water nowadays.

The bruising thing is a misnomer, the real difference is the amount of dilution and chilling present. People who strongly prefer stirred martinis do so out of an aversion to the ice flakes and extra chilling (once again numbing the complexity of the spirit) that shaking adds.

name: terebikun
text: I always have my whiskey/whisky neat, or maybe with a water back.  It's gotta be room temperature, or the taste is just off

name: fuzzyshoo
text:
My friend's wedding last year: Open bar, $6 for a glass of Blue Label. Not a glass with 2 ice cubes and a tiny bit of scotch, we're talking a full highball of a typically $25-40 glass of scotch.

It was heavenly.

name: presterjohn
text: Scotch Highland Style should be taken neat with ice water on the side. You alternate sips of scotch and water until you're too donked to appreciate good scotch, at which point you switch to something cheaper.

name: spinynorman
text: Yep. If you drink a bottle of single malt in one night, you have probably wasted about half the bottle.

name: terribleman
text:
You shouldn't be too proud to get drunk in the expensive stuff. It can be a rewarding experience under the right circumstances. No better medicine for a heartache, for example.

I only add a few drops of water if it's a new whiskey I want to try and decipher all the flavours in. Otherwise I take it straight up, at room temperature. I like the shock of the alcohol, and I actually find myself going for the heavier voltage the older I get. I crave the crass stuff.

name: lordpretzel
text: He also lacks the class to allow any flavor to remain in his meat.

name: patkun
text: Is Ray's computer always as huge as that, or has he borrowed Onstad's?

name: woodenteeth
text: Panel 5 is a bit of an art low light. I'm down with the simple line art but Ray's hand in Panel 5 looks a bit like some kind of weird growth.

name: fuckyoufriday
text: Hunt's : Heinz :: Hanna-Barbera : Disney

name: stuart
text: A comment left by stuart was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by goocifer, Tagrineth, YossarianLives, nutmeg, dr_sexlove)

name: soticoto
text:
Just what the hell is "Hunt's" anyway? I've never even heard of it. Is it some sort of american thing?

Honestly, I thought Heinz was cheap crap until I realised the company had bought out HP Sauce... which kinda sucks since I love HP Sauce.

O'course it is Tabasco that I put on everything, and that is another subject entirely.

name: fineoakstructure
text:
Hunt's might be considered the low man's ketchup, one-step down from Heinz. Hunt's, as it were, is not Fancy.

Though, frankly, you can do much worse than Hunt's. I've noticed more local bars in my area have switched to a ketchup by the name of Monarch, I believe.

name: soticoto
text: Burger King sachets.

name: shutup_shutup
text: I'm forced to assume that it's the same Monarch that makes cheap liquors.

name: fineoakstructure
text: If there's a Monarch brand that makes cheap liquors, does that mean the Aristocrat brand makes even cheaper liquors?

name: jackfruit
text: Hunt's is a mullet in ketchup form

name: dasilodavi
text: Hunt's is ketchup for a man of such low means.

name: dj_insomniac
text: Hunt's is ketchup for men of low mind.

name: cheezeburger
text:
Frankly, a "player" who orders his pizza from Domino's has no business judging another man's eating habits.

[url=http://achewood.com/index.php?date=08202004]See here[/url

name: professorhazard
text: O'Malley has two moms, and they both have hips so bad that Ray knows about it.

name: spectre
text: Wasn't that the book that got banned from Brooklyn schools, "O'Mally Has Two Mommies"?

name: professorhazard
text: I Saw Mayor C. Kissing Mommy on the Titties

name: foxtrotamend
text: Ray, why do you keep putting your cocktail up there if it's just gonna keep falling off?

name: tekende
text: Ray is not mindful of good sense.

name: kleptonis
text: A well done filet? What is that man thinking.

name: stormagnet
text: I picture him ordering all the most expensive things on the menu in an attempt to cover for his background.

name: farqussus
text: HOW ASTUTE

name: autrepoupee
text: Red Gold is my ketchup of choice, what does that say about my background?  I never see anyone even speak on Red Gold, anywhere.  It's like the ketchup time forgot, livin in the land of the lost.

name: lawbot
text:
What is it like? The ketchup that I have in my fridge is Tesco Finest Ketchup. It seems to be a combination of pulverised sundried tomatoes, tomato pureee, and molasses. Some lemon and vinegar.

It is not a good ketchup.

name: lawbot
text: As it happens I know the heir to a graft fortune, from Florida, and he orders his steak well done. Nice guy, but he really does do that.

name: lunchbox
text: It's different with filets. They're pretty tasteless without the redness or a good marinade, and their tenderness is the main attraction, so ordering it rare (mid-rare at the absolute most) is the main thing to do.

name: jasper
text:
I have to tell you...
blini are not potato pancakes. latkes are potato pancakes. blini are essentially crepes; they're made with flour, or buckwheat.

name: terribleman
text: Well, what does a dick know about this stuff?

name: vance
text: My ex-fiancee would cringe. She worked at a very prestigious steakhouse (how they get that way, I'll never know) and was so adamant about steak being medium rare, all the time, that I can't even order my burgers any other way when asked.
